summary: Performers of the Year: Killing Eve's Jodie Comer and Sandra Oh
title: Performers of the Year: Killing Eve's Jodie Comer and Sandra Oh
excerpt: Last week, we here at TVLine revealed our 20 finalists for the title of Performer of the Year. We’ve reviewed your suggestions, we’ve debated fiercely among ourselves, and now we’…
description:
Comer, a relative newcomer, made us sit up and pay attention from her very first scenes as Villanelle, flashing a devilish smile after maliciously dumping a cup of ice cream into a child’s lap. It was a true breakout performance, with Comer effortlessly handling Villanelle’s vicious wisecracks, seductive femininity and brutal bloodlust — sometimes all in the same scene. (How the hell did she not get an Emmy nomination again?) We already knew Oh from her days on Grey’s Anatomy, of course, and it wasn’t easy taking our attention away from Comer, but she delivered a marvelously versatile performance of her own. Ranging from dogged pursuit to burnt-out vulnerability, Oh’s Eve was our whip-smart window into this world, as she discovered an inner strength she never knew she had while chasing Villanelle across the globe.

Comer and Oh were great enough on their own, but when they shared the screen together, they were absolutely electrifying. (We have four words for you: The. Shepherd’s. Pie. Scene.) The two actors brought out the best in each other all season long, with Eve and Villanelle harboring a passionate mutual obsession that culminated in a shocking final showdown — and by season’s end, we were obsessed, too. Now we just have to (impatiently) wait for Season 2 to get here…

summary: GLOW and Killing Eve Gave Bad Girls a Chance to Be Good
title: GLOW and Killing Eve Gave Bad Girls a Chance to Be Good
excerpt: In the ring or on a killing spree, pat morality was overturned.
description:
Out of the ring, Debbie is also nothing like her golden-warrior persona. She’s a newly single mother, recently divorced, who is not just lonely and sad but also furious and angry. While Ruth is constantly trying to make things up to Debbie and always looking out for the other women—she’s the group’s actual leader, their director—Debbie is often high on her own supply, imperious and haughty. Debbie can be awful—she breaks Ruth’s leg, for goodness’ sake!—but even when doing these awful things, she’s understandable and sympathetic, thanks both to the writing and to Gilpin’s incredible performance. The point of GLOW isn’t that the good girl is actually the bad girl and the bad girl the good girl. It’s that there are no bad girls and no good girls; everyone’s all mixed up. Debbie’s a rejoinder to all the simplistic versions—both gentle and harsh—of the wronged woman that have ever been written.

All to say: You can tell GLOW was created by women. And you can tell this about Killing Eve too, which was created by Fleabag’s Phoebe Waller-Bridge. Waller-Bridge completely revitalized what I had heretofore considered a total dead end: the psycho-killer show. One way that Waller-Bridge did that was to make her psycho killer incredibly fun—a potentially icky move that worked for me because it felt so mindful, instead of mindless.

by Willa Paskin

Click through above for the rest.

tags: she read the emotional state of the mole and knew he was still off-edge because of his near-death and she knew this was all it would take
summary: Another cool moment in this show is the safe house scenes, where the muscle-y guys are like “You want me to drag him in by the...
body:
Another cool moment in this show is the safe house scenes, where the muscle-y guys are like “You want me to drag him in by the armpits?” But then Carolyn is like, ‘No. I know exactly what he needs. I’m so sorry you have to see this.’

and this is how she interrogates/gets the intel from him:

the tough guy act wouldn’t have worked, but Carolyn pretending to be more maternal and caring than she actually is to trick this guy DID

another cool way of wielding ‘femininity’ as a weapon
